inlineContent.text: A big OMG moment this week has been setting up cloudflare workers with
blog! It’s my personal internet space and process of me writing to publishing should be as quick as possible. However, it is crazy how similar it is to
, a blog I started in 2013! The web works in both fast and slow ways. The feeling of deja-vu is here and I’m feeling old. In fact, the initial content for my blog will come from those original posts.

After another week of exploration, the notion community continues to impress. Notion has this uncanny ability to be really simple to setup but hard to master. But not really hard, just sufficiently hard. In fact this is a common gaming pattern! Every level of understanding the product creates a sense of accomplishment. Small “Aha!” moments littered throughout the way. They even out right use gamification by giving users credits in order to get to know their product.

abstract.text: This might sound weird, but my experience acting is the most relevant study/project/work I’ve done to prepare me as a developer.

TL;DR: Apple has been refining their location APIs opportunistically to improve battery life.

In the world of programming languages, Swift has emerged as a dynamic and versatile option. Its type inference feature, while powerful, isn’t without its quirks. Like any technological innovation, Swift’s type inference has its own set of performance considerations that developers should be aware of. In this blog post, we’ll delve into the fascinating realm of Swift’s type inference and explore how it can sometimes impose performance penalties.

doc://me.rismay.site/documentation/Risma.title: Navigating the Performance Penalties of Swift Type Inference
Swift’s Struct Packing and Memory Dynamics, Inherited from C
$1500 13” Late 2013 rMBP vs $1600 15” 2012 rMBP? Portability vs Performance

abstract.text: I previously posted that I returned my Late 2013 13” rMBP after I encountered the dreaded unresponsive keyboard glitch. This is a bit disingenuous because the ultimate reason I returned the notebook was to purchase a more powerful version of the same laptop after the Keyboard/Trackpad problems were confirmed to be software issues. However, when I went to look at my buying options, I discover that Apple was offering the original 2012 15” rMBP for $1600. That’s $500 off for a laptop that comes with a 1 year warranty. This post is simply to help those wondering: Should you pay $100 more for a refurbished original 15” Retina Macbook Pro vs a new Late 2013 13” MacBook Pro Retina?
An engineer and designer focused on developer tools, creative systems, and agentic workflows.
